channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Carney Lifts Climate Laws for New Alberta Pipeline
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney reached a tentative deal with the province as part of his program to curb the country’s economic dependence on the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney with Premier Danielle Smith of Alberta on Thursday in Calgary.

item.title: Robert A.M. Stern, Architect Who Reinvented Prewar Splendor, Dies at 86
item.description: He designed museums, schools and libraries before winning international acclaim late in life for 15 Central Park West in Manhattan, hailed as a rebirth of the luxury apartment building.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:description: Robert A.M. Stern in 2007. Glowing reviews drove a stampede of celebrities to 15 CPW — the building he described as “my breakthrough” — overshadowing the competition from sleek glass towers that had been the rage in Manhattan early in the new millennium.

item.title: Black Friday Deals Can Put People in Debt. Here’s How to Manage It.
item.description: The convenience of one-click purchases and “buy now, pay later” loans is making it easier for people to shop — and shop and shop — during the holidays.
item.dc:creator: Juli Fraga and Connie Chang
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kristen Conti, 60, sought help after spending more than $1,000 on Labubu dolls and Christmas decorations. She has over $50,000 in credit card debt.

item.title: Sean Duffy Longs for the ‘Golden Days’ of Air Travel. What Was That Like?
item.description: Back in the ’50s and ’60s, passengers (well-dressed, of course, and with perfect manners) could count on hot meals on china, plenty of legroom, the occasional piano bar, even wool blankets. Those days are gone.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy
item.media:credit: Pictorial Parade/Archive Photos, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Fewer people flew in the 1960s, which allowed airlines to use the extra space for lounges where people drank and socialized.

item.title: Gen X-ers Have Money to Spend. Why Are Retailers Ignoring Them?
item.description: Three in four Americans ages 45 to 60 say they expect to overspend for the holidays. They’re “sort of like the glue within the consumer spectrum.”
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone

item.title: During the Holidays, Retailers Want Social Media Attention
item.description: Experts say that keeping holiday posts festive but not focused on sales is an effective strategy.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Felder
item.category: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Paris department store Samaritaine Paris Pont-Neuf has a giant Advent calendar with numbers positioned along its grand staircase. Patrons can learn of the surprise behind each date in the store or by watching Samaritaine’s Instagram Stories.

item.title: Campbell’s Says Executive Accused of Offensive Remarks Has Left the Company
item.description: The comments came to light after an audiotape was released, tied to a lawsuit filed by a former employee.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:description: Campbell’s said it learned about an audiotape reportedly featuring the voice of a company executive when a lawsuit was filed last week.

item.title: U.K. Budget Plan Calms Markets and Labour Faithful. Will It Appeal to Voters?
item.description: The plan presented by the chancellor of the Exchequer, Rachel Reeves, called for spending increases and higher taxes on the wealthy and the middle class.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Rachel Reeves, Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, carries a red box symbolizing the presentation of a new government budget on Wednesday in London.

item.title: As Prices Pinch, Bessent Looks for Ways to Mollify Wary Consumers
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has offered a variety of creative justifications for President Trump’s import duties.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Secretary of the Treasury Scott Bessent speaking to the press at the White House in November. Mr. Bessent has stifled his skepticism about tariffs since being tapped by Mr. Trump for the Treasury role.

item.title: Kevin Hassett Reportedly Becomes Front-Runner for Fed Chair
item.description: Kevin Hassett, a top White House economic adviser, is said to become the front-runner to lead the Federal Reserve, raising questions about its independence.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kevin Hassett, a close economic adviser to President Trump, has reportedly emerged as a front-runner to be the next Fed chair.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.description: Firefighters tried to douse the blaze at an apartment complex in the city’s northern Tai Po district, which killed at least four people.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Joy Dong, Keith Bradsher, Anushka Patil and Tina Zhou

item.title: Retail Earnings Show Shoppers’ Resilience, but Some Stores Struggle
item.description: Companies said they managed tariff pressures in the latest quarter as consumers focused on discounts and high quality.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Black Friday shoppers at a mall in Albany, N.Y., last year. The holiday shopping season is a critical period for retailers.

item.title: Disney’s ‘Zootopia 2’ Will Be a Test for Jared Bush
item.description: Jared Bush is trying to make the heart of the media empire beat more consistently. “Zootopia 2” will be a test.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:credit: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jared Bush, as Disney Animation’s new chief creative officer, is charged with getting the studio back on track.

item.title: Donors to Trump’s Transition Revealed a Year Later
item.description: A 46-person list includes billionaires and people he went on to appoint to positions of power.
item.dc:creator: Ken Bensinger and David A. Fahrenthold
item.media:description: As president-elect, Donald J. Trump refused federal funds for his presidential transition, which would have required contributors to be disclosed within 30 days of taking office.

item.title: Britain Raises Taxes by More Than $30 Billion in Push for ‘Stable Economy’
item.description: In announcing the measures, Rachel Reeves, the top economic official in an increasingly unpopular government, cited the forecasts for slower growth and the need to hold down debt.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Pru/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Rachel Reeves, the chancellor of the Exchequer, announces the government’s annual budget in Parliament on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Announces Negotiated Prices for 15 Drugs Under Medicare
item.description: The Trump administration said that had the new prices been in effect last year, Medicare would have saved $12 billion, which would have reduced its spending on those drugs by 44 percent.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: The 15 drugs include widely used inhalers, such as Breo Ellipta, and treatments for cancer, diabetes and depression.

item.title: How Much Will Thanksgiving Dinner Cost? It Depends on Whom You Ask.
item.description: As Americans become increasingly concerned about affordability, there’s scrutiny on the annual meal.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Draper

item.title: Binance Is Sued by Oct. 7 Victims’ Families, Accused of Aiding Terrorism
item.description: A lawsuit claims the cryptocurrency exchange turned a blind eye as $1 billion used to finance the Oct. 7 attacks in Israel and other acts moved through its network.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley
item.media:description: Changpeng Zhao, Binance’s founder, was convicted of money laundering in 2023 and pardoned by President Trump in late October.

item.title: Market Volatility Underscores Epic Buildup of Global Risk
item.description: Some experts see a dangerous combination of factors reminiscent of practices that led to previous financial crises.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: A conference held by Nvidia in Washington last month. The company’s multi-trillion-dollar valuation assumes endless growth.

item.title: The Fed and Big Tech Re-Raise Investors’ Spirits
item.description: Markets appear to be hoping again that the central bank will cut rates next month, and that the artificial intelligence boom has room to run.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Ian Mount and David Meyer
item.media:description: Indications that the Fed may cut interest rates next month have helped lift the S&P 500.

item.title: China and Japan, With Trump in the Middle, Are in a Showdown
item.description: With Japan’s new leader refusing to back down from China’s show of force and claims on Taiwan, Xi Jinping picks up the phone to try to pry the U.S.-Japan alliance apart.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and River Akira Davis
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Trump and Xi Jinping meeting in Busan, South Korea, in October. A phone call on Monday between the two leaders came as tensions have risen between China and Japan.

item.title: What Is Agentic A.I., and Would You Trust It to Book a Flight?
item.description: Companies are racing to develop artificial intelligence tools that can make reservations for flights, hotels and more on your behalf. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root
item.media:credit: Christopher Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: New A.I. tools could soon have the power to monitor prices and book without any action from travelers, using their credit card numbers.

item.title: A Frugal Guide to St. Martin/St. Maarten
item.description: The dual-nation island of Dutch St. Maarten and French St. Martin offers lots of frugal diversions, including vivid street murals, hilly hikes and local barbecue.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac and Hiroko Masuike

item.title: Trump’s Trade War Has Canadians ‘Elbows Up’ for Homegrown Wine
item.description: The trade war with the United States, bans on U.S. wine and liquor imports and a recent distributor strike in British Columbia have Canadians giving their homegrown wines another look.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.media:credit: Jennilee Marigomen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bar at the Cannon Estate Winery in Abbotsford, British Columbia. Sales there have increased by 66 percent this year.

item.title: A.I. Can Do More of Your Shopping This Holiday Season
item.description: New tools and features from retailers and tech companies use artificial intelligence to help people find gifts and make decisions about their shopping lists.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha and Kailyn Rhone

item.title: Trump Administration Is Taking Billions in Stakes in Firms Like Intel
item.description: The Trump administration is spending billions of dollars on deals with ownership stakes in companies. The unusual practice shows no sign of slowing.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: MP Materials, which owns rare earth mines in California, is among the private companies in which the Trump administration has acquired an ownership stake.

item.title: Faux Jewels and Slimming Belts: Why Shopping on TikTok Is a Lot Like QVC
item.description: The popular app’s online marketplace is growing rapidly in the United States, driven by TikTok’s popularity and influencer advertisements that look a lot like TV infomercials.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner

item.title: Boeing Tackles Quality With a ‘War on Defects’
item.description: Two years after a panel flew off a 737 Max, Boeing is doing more inspections, completing work in its intended order and making other changes. Can the company keep it up?
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: The number of 737 Max planes that Boeing can make every month was limited by federal regulators after a door plug blew away from a plane during a 2024 flight.

item.title: Budget Will Be a Big Test for the UK’s Most Unpopular Chancellor in Decades
item.description: Rachel Reeves, who has had a bruising tenure as the country’s top economic official, is set to announce tax and spending measures that risk stoking more discontent.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: Rachel Reeves, who was named Britain’s chancellor last year under a new Labour government, has come to embody the country’s economic challenges.

item.title: GLP-1 Drug Fails to Quell Alzheimer’s in Novo Nordisk Trials
item.description: The studies were a setback for the optimistic view that semaglutide and other drugs used in obesity and diabetes treatment could help prevent a number of brain diseases.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:description: A trial of semaglutide, the miracle drug branded as Ozempic and Wegovy for diabetes and weight loss, failed to find any effect of the drug on cognition and functioning in people with mild cognitive impairment or dementia.

item.title: Consumer Bureau’s Bank Examiners Criticize New ‘Humility Pledge’
item.description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said it would require a vow to “work collaboratively” with companies before beginning a review.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: In a notice, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau described its own supervision department as “the weaponized arm” of the agency under its Biden-era director.

item.title: Xi Presses Trump on Taiwan as They Agree to Meet in China in April
item.description: In an unusual move, Xi Jinping, the leader of China, called President Trump. The two spoke about trade, Taiwan and Ukraine, according to separate official statements.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson, Alan Rappeport and Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Trump with Xi Jinping, China’s leader, last month. Mr. Trump said that they had a “very good telephone call” on Monday.

item.title: An Auto Holy Grail: Motors That Don’t Rely on Chinese Rare Earths
item.description: Weary of being captive to geopolitics, car companies are looking for ways to replace powerful rare-earth magnets in electric motors.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing

item.title: Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine Prompts Debate Over Europe’s Military
item.description: With Russia looming, governments race to rebuild armed forces that shrank after the Cold War, grappling with hard issues of economics, politics and military strategy.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Finnish Army conscripts at a training exercise in Helsinki. Finland maintained conscription after the fall of the Soviet Union.

item.title: Why Crypto’s Slide Is Rattling Wall Street
item.description: Bitcoin and other digital tokens have lost more than $1 trillion in value in recent weeks, raising concerns about a wider market fallout.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Ian Mount and Grady McGregor
item.media:description: A recent slump in crypto prices has rattled investors.

item.title: Trump Welcomes A.P.’s Photographers. Its Reporters? Not So Much.
item.description: The White House now has conflicting approaches for Associated Press journalists as it fights the news service in court over access to presidential events.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wemple
item.media:description: While the White House has restored access to Associated Press photographers like Evan Vucci, it continues to exclude A.P. reporters from the presidential press pool.

item.title: Why Europe and the United States Are Still Haggling on Trade
item.description: While the two sides reached a broad agreement months ago, American officials visited Brussels this week to discuss the details. Europe has a wish list, but so does the United States.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: The United States is seeking to conclude a binding, written agreement with the European Union, four months after Ursula von der Leyen, the top E.U. official, and President Trump made a handshake deal.

item.title: Trade Chaos Leads Small Businesses to Rethink U.S. Relationships
item.description: From Sweden to Brazil, six small companies talk about how they are communicating with their U.S. customers amid uncertainty over Trump’s changing tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov
item.media:credit: Cesar Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Víctor Feliu at his chocolate company in Mexico. The changing rules for sending goods to the United States have forced him to pause his U.S. shipments.

item.title: How One German Toymaker Made Money Despite Trump’s Tariffs
item.description: A combination of strategic planning, good timing and a long-awaited product helped the maker of electronic story boxes weather the onset of tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Patrick Junker
item.media:description: A popular audio player, Toniebox. Toy sales in the United States are up, despite new tariffs, which contributed to, on average, a 4 percent increase in retail prices, according to Circana, a marketing research firm.

item.title: U.S. Introduces New Female Crash-Test Dummy Standards
item.description: A female crash-test dummy to replace an outdated model largely based on male proportions would improve safety for women, who face higher fatality and injury risks on the road, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: A THOR-05F female crash-test dummy in Farmington Hills, Mich.

item.title: How Parents Talk to Kids About Money, Privilege and Inequality
item.description: Some parents turn to books or family movie nights to facilitate discussions. But they admit they don’t have all the answers.
item.dc:creator: Kristin Wong
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Adults know about social, economic, cultural issues, but kids don’t understand all that yet,” said Catherine Collins, with her twins, Edison and Aria, in Clarendon Hills, Ill.

item.title: Hedge Fund Titan Has a Turnaround Plan (for the Carolina Panthers)
item.description: David Tepper, the founder of the $20 billion Appaloosa Management, may have finally cracked the winning code for his flagging N.F.L. team.
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson and Maureen Farrell
item.media:credit: Logan R. Cyrus for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Tepper, attending a September practice, bought the Carolina Panthers in 2018 for a record $2.3 billion.

item.title: A Swath of Bank Customer Data Was Hacked. The F.B.I. Is Investigating.
item.description: SitusAMC, a technology vendor for real estate lenders, holds sensitive personal information on the clients of hundreds of its banking customers, including JPMorgan Chase.
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland, Stacy Cowley and Devlin Barrett
item.media:description: JPMorgan Chase was among the banks notified by SitusAMC that its client data may have been breached.

item.title: ‘Wicked: For Good’ Takes Flight at Box Office, Expected to Make Over $150 Million
item.description: The movie is expected to take in about $150 million from Friday through Sunday, earning 34 percent more than the first installment last year.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:description: Cast members at the premiere of “Wicked: For Good” in New York on Monday. Its opening weekend was the second biggest of the year.

item.title: A.I. Toy Bear Speaks of Sex, Knives and Pills, Consumer Group Warns
item.description: The chatter left startled adults unsure whether they heard correctly. Testers warned that interactive toys like this one could allow children to stray into inappropriate exchanges.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.media:description: A screen shot of the FoloToy website, advertising its A.I.-enabled stuffed bear, named Kumma.

item.title: The Rise of the ‘Just in Case’ M.R.I.
item.description: A growing batch of companies give customers access to whatever medical tests they want — no doctor’s orders required.
item.dc:creator: Brent Crane

item.title: Daily Mail Owner Agrees to Buy The Telegraph, Consolidating Right-Leaning Media in Britain
item.description: The deal would combine two of the country’s major newspaper groups, a move likely to attract antitrust scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:credit: Richard A. Brooks/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Copies of British newspaper The Telegraph.

item.title: The A.I. Boom Is Driving the Economy. What Happens if It Falters?
item.description: A windfall for companies that build data centers and their suppliers is overshadowing weakness in other industries.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman and Sydney Ember

item.title: Miss Piggy, Fraggles and an Auction at the Twilight of a Hollywood Era
item.description: The Jim Henson Company sold its longtime studio and is auctioning Muppets memorabilia for the first time in its 70-year history.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes and Michelle Groskopf
item.media:description: Miss Piggy’s shoes from “The Great Muppet Caper” could go for $7,000 or “Hi-yah!”
